description: From Middle English newes, newys (“new things”), equivalent to new (noun) +‎ -s. Compare Saterland Frisian Näis (“news”), East Frisian näjs ("news"), West Frisian nijs (“news”), Dutch nieuws (“news”), German Low German Neeis (“new things; news”). Often erroneously said to be an acronym of "North, East, West, South" or "Noteworthy Events, Weather, Sports".

examples: Is there any news about the storm?
That was not much news in the press release.

entries.meaning: Information about current events disseminated via media.
examples: Did you hear/read/see the latest news?
The news is that a new leader will be elected in one month.
I heard about the earthquake on the morning news.

verbs.description: news (third-person singular simple present newses, present participle newsing, simple past and past participle newsed)

entries.meaning: (transitive, archaic) To report; to make known.
examples: This remark was newsed abroad; whereupon the loyal authorities of Lerwick immediately had the revolutionary skipper arrested, on a charge of high treason.
